data.title: Harry Saunders (Roud 55; Child 87)
data.text:
> Folk Music > Songs > Prince Robert / Lord Abore and Mary Flynn / Harry Saunders

Prince Robert / Lord Abore and Mary Flynn / Harry Saunders

[ Roud 55 ; Child 87 ; Ballad Index C087 ; Prince Robert at Fire Draw Near ; DT PRINROBT , LORDABOR ; Mudcat 15291 , 92365 ; trad.]

The Oxford Book of Ballads

Frank Feeney learned Lord OÃ¢Â€Â™Bore â€œfrom his wife who was a Carlow womanâ€. He sang it at home in Galloping Green, Foxrock, Co Dublin, on 5 December 1970 to Tom Munnelly and Hugh Shields. Jim Kelly learned Lord Abore from Frank Feeney and sang it to Tom Munnelly in OÃ¢Â€Â™DonoghueÃ¢Â€Â™s pub, Merrion Row, Dublin, in May 1970. Both recordings were included in 1985 on the Folk Music Society of Ireland anthology Early Ballads in Ireland 1968-1985, which was reissued on CD in 2015 by An GoÃƒÂ­lÃƒÂ­n.

Peggy Seeger sang Harry Saunders in 1976 on her and Ewan MacCollÃ¢Â€Â™s Larrikin album No Tyme Lyke the Present. She noted:

In the ballads, blood flows thicker than water, and a good deal more often. The bulk of the strife is in the family, but it is rare to find a mother killing her sonâ€”her baby boy perhaps, but not her grown son. It is common, however, in both life and art to find conflict between the mother and the sonÃ¢Â€Â™s wife. In Harry Saunders (given the title of Prince Robert by Child) the struggle culminates in the death of the son. In one of ChildÃ¢Â€Â™s texts, there is a revealing verse:

It is the fashion in oor countrie, mither,

I dinna ken what it is here,

To like your wife better than your mither,

That â€¦ bought you sae dear.

In spite of the missing words, the meaning is clear. But the ballad is very rare. It is from the singing of F.C. Gainer of Tanner, Gilmer County, West Virginia.

Al OÃ¢Â€Â™Donnell sang Lord Abore and Mary Flynn in 1978 on his Transatlantic / The Leader Tradition album Al OÃ¢Â€Â™Donnell 2.

Jackie Oates sang Lord Abore and Mary Flynn in 2006 on her eponymous first album Jackie Oates. She noted:

This is an Irish version of Child ballad 87 Prince Robert taught to me by Sean OÃ¢Â€Â™Shee of Exeter. The song is a harrowing insight into the consequences of a motherÃ¢Â€Â™s overbearing motherliness!

Ewan McLennan sang Prince Robert in 2014 on his Fellside album Stories Still Untold. He commented:

This is a folk song that is typical of the more dark and epic murder stories involving parentsÃ¢Â€Â™ jealousy and fury towards a marriage they see as unacceptable.

It first appeared in ScottÃ¢Â€Â™s Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border in 1802 and became â€˜Child #87â€™ in Francis J. ChildÃ¢Â€Â™s seminal collection The English and Scottish Popular Ballads, where he published several variations of the text. In this recording IÃ¢Â€Â™m singing the text version from MotherwellÃ¢Â€Â™s Minstrelsy Ancient and Modern collected from a Mrs Thompson. Although it shares some â€˜floating versesâ€™, the story in Prince Robert seems to be unique amongst the classic ballads.

The words were never printed with music and the melody that might have been sung with this ballad has been long lost. After trying, without great result, to write music for the song I put it to the tune of a similar Irish ballad, Lord Abore and Mary Flynnâ€”it seems to work.

Steve Byrne sang Prince Robert on the 2019 album ScottÃ¢Â€Â™s Sangs that revisited the ballads of Walter ScottÃ¢Â€Â™s Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border. Emily Lyle noted:

According to Scott, this ballad is derived â€œfrom the recitation of a lady, nearly related to the Editorâ€, namely his motherÃ¢Â€Â™s sister in Edinburgh, Miss Christian Rutherford. It is a unique song that has not been recorded in the Scots song tradition in living memory.

However, a rare version was found in Ireland in 1970 by ballad collector Tom Munnelly (1944-2007). Tom recorded it as Lord Abore and Mary Flynn from two singers in County Dublin, Jim Kelly and Frank Feeney (d. 1982). Feeney in turn had heard it from his late wife, who is not named, from County Carlow. The story of the songÃ¢Â€Â™s discovery is documented in Irish Folk Music Studies Vol. 1 (1972-3). Tom Munnelly passed the song on to Dublin singer A1 OÃ¢Â€Â™Donnell (1943-2015) who recorded it on the album Al OÃ¢Â€Â™Donnell 2 in 1978, which is where Steve Byrne first heard it, and found the melody fitted ScottÃ¢Â€Â™s words well. It is thought that â€˜Lord Aboreâ€™ or â€˜OÃ¢Â€Â™Boreâ€™ is a â€˜mondegreenâ€™, or mishearing, of â€˜Lord Robertâ€™.

Lankum sang Lord Abore and Mary Flynn in 2023 on their Rough Trade album False Lankum. They noted:

Lord Abore and Mary Flynn is an Irish version of the ballad Prince Robert (Child 87). Although Scottish in origin, this is the only version that could safely be said to have survived in the tradition. Although there is a related American ballad called Harry Saunders, this appears to be a relatively modern recreation of the song. It was thought to be extinct in this part of the world until the song collector Tom Munnelly happened to hear it being sung in a Dublin pub in 1969. The singer was Jim Kelly who had learnt it from Frank Feeney of Galloping Green, who in turn had learned it from his wife, a Carlow woman, whose name is, unfortunately, not noted. The two men can be heard singing their respective versions of the song on the album Early Ballads in Ireland 1968-1985.

Lyrics

Frank Feeney sings Lord OÃ¢Â€Â™Bore

Lord OÃ¢Â€Â™Bore and Mary Flynn

The two were children young,

They were scarcely fourteen years of age

When love between them sprung,

When love between them sprung.

Lord OÃ¢Â€Â™Bore was going out one day

And says his mother to him,

â€œYouÃ¢Â€Â™re going away, dear son,â€ she says,

â€œYouÃ¢Â€Â™ll drink before youÃ¢Â€Â™ll go,

Oh, youÃ¢Â€Â™ll drink before youÃ¢Â€Â™ll go.â€

She brought him down a bottle of wine

And filled a glass for him,

With her false, her false, with her two fingers

She put strong poison in,

Oh, she put strong poison in.

â€œOh why, oh why dear mother,â€ he says,

â€œYouÃ¢Â€Â™ve poisoned me full sore?

â€œOh indeed itÃ¢Â€Â™s true, dear son,â€ she says,

â€œYouÃ¢Â€Â™ll see Mary Flynn no more,

Oh, youÃ¢Â€Â™ll see Mary Flynn no more.â€

â€œIs there anybody in this house,â€ he says,

â€œWould go on a message for me,

Would go unto Mary FlynnÃ¢Â€Â™s tower

And bring her here to me,

Oh, bring her here to me?â€

Up spoke a pretty-faced little boy

Who was his sisterÃ¢Â€Â™s son:

â€œOh, I often went on your message before

But itÃ¢Â€Â™s now I have need to run,

Oh, itÃ¢Â€Â™s now I have need to run.â€

â€œWhere are you going, my pretty little boy,

Or what brought you here to me?

Your grandma Ã¢Â€Â™pared a place for you

And now invited thee,

Oh, now invited thee.â€

â€œYour grandma Ã¢Â€Â™pared no place for me

Nor either invited thee.â€

And soon she guessed of her pretty little boy

That Lord OÃ¢Â€Â™Bore was dead,

Oh, Lord OÃ¢Â€Â™Bore was dead.

â€œCome saddle for me the swiftest horse,

Come saddle for me the bay.

Come saddle for me the swiftest horse

That ever ran that way,

Oh, that ever ran that way.â€

When she went to Lord OÃ¢Â€Â™BoreÃ¢Â€Â™s tower

She stepped into the hall,

Oh, the sheets were spread and the torches burnâ€¦

â€œWhat brought you here, Mary Flynn?â€ she says,

â€œWhat brought you here to me?â€

â€œOh, the ring thatÃ¢Â€Â™s on his little finger

I came to crave of thee,

Oh, I came to crave of thee.â€

â€œNo ring, no ring, Mary Flynnâ€ she says,

â€œNo ring have I for thee.

For the pain of death it came so quick,

It split the ring in three,

Oh, it split the ring in three.

She laid her feet beneath his feet,

Her side down by his side.

She laid her head beneath his head

And immediately she died,

Oh, immediately she died.

Jim Kelly sings Lord Abore

Lord Abore and Mary Flynn

Were both children young,

They were scarcely fourteen years of age

Jackie Oates sings Lord Abore and Mary Flynn

Lord Abore and Mary Flynn were both children young,

Scare but thirteen years of age, love between them sprung.

Now Lord Abore was going out one day and when his mother came to know,

â€œYou are going away, my son,â€ she said, â€œyou will drink before you go.â€

SheÃ¢Â€Â™s fetched a cask of the very best wine and poured a glass for him,

But false, false with her two fingers she put strong poison in.

And, â€œWhy, oh why, my mother,â€ he said, â€œhave you poisoned me full sore?â€

â€œIt is so, my own young son,â€ she said, â€œYou will see Mary Flynn no more,

You shall see Mary Flynn no more.â€

â€œIs there anybody here in this household will go on an errand for me?

Who will go to Mary FlynnÃ¢Â€Â™s high tower and send her here to me?â€

Then up and spoke a little serving boy, â€œIÃ¢Â€Â™m your faithful man,â€ says he,

â€œI will go to Mary FlynnÃ¢Â€Â™s high tower and send her here to thee.â€

And when heÃ¢Â€Â™s got to her high tower and walked into the hall,

Oh the tables were laid and the sheets outspread, and the candles burning all.

â€œHow came you here?â€ Mary Flynn she said, â€œHow came you here to me?

Has my grandmother set a place for you or yet invited thee?â€

â€œNo, your grandmotherÃ¢Â€Â™s not set a place for me or invited me,â€ he said,

And then he told this Mary Flynn that Lord Abore was dead,

That Lord Abore was dead.

â€œGo saddle me my bonny white steed, go saddle me my grey,

That I might ride to his high tower without the least delay.â€

And when sheÃ¢Â€Â™s got to his high tower and walked into the hall,

Oh the tables were laid and the sheets outspread, and the candles burning all.

â€œHow came you here, Mary Flynn?â€ she said, â€œHow came you here to me?â€

â€œOh the ring that was on his left finger IÃ¢Â€Â™ve come to begot of thee.â€

â€œNo ring, no ring, Mary Flynn,â€ she said, â€œNo ring have I for thee,

For the pain of death it came so sharp, it split the ring in three.â€
